tools/gate/selenium/grafanaSelenium.py.message: Curious if these selenium tests should do some assert's or other automated checks to validate things than just time outs. Taking screenshot is great, but that involves person to check.

This is a good point. I suppose the thought is, if the script exits early, then something isn't working right. However I've noticed that when these scripts get run by Zuul, they're run || true.

In the other selenium scripts we have, the ones in the nagios and grafana charts, the tests are run as a part of the chart deployment. If those tests exit early, the failure is more disruptive than these.

This makes me wonder if these gate scripts are worthwhile as they are used currently. Perhaps this work would be better suited to live in the osh-selenium image, and all charts which could be tested by selenium be updated to use it (Ie, kibana and prometheus)?

tox.ini.message:
This would seem to cover a very limited set of yaml files, as it won't run lint on files in subdirs:

$ find playbookconfig/ -name *.yml | wc -l
54
$ ls playbookconfig/src/playbooks/*.yml | wc -l
5

Also, is the "-n 1" needed? Can ansible-lint only take one file as an argument?
I can adjust the xargs values.

Ok, so the arguments to ansible-lint are the playbooks, and the yaml files in subdirs are "tasks", which appear to get analyzed in processing the playbooks.

Calling with -n 1 causes some repetition, however, as some of these tasks get analyzed multiple times. Dropping the -n 1 (and using --no-run-if-empty, if concerned about no playbooks present) results in the same set of files getting analyzed, but without the repetition.

tripleo_common/image/image_uploader.py.message: This is the quick check where we don't actually refetch the layer because it already exists. But at you can see it is in lock section.
This is the function under threading/python2 that basically turns it single threaded.

So the issues that switching the executor from thread to process addresses is still not solved by this patch. The problem is the concurrent IO done when fetching the layers when run under python2 effectively makes this single threaded.

Please see https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1847225
The snippets I placed there illustrate that real multiple fetching happens (to my understanding)?

I believe it's a py2 problem when dealing with the IO. The rhel8 jobs don't exhibit the same problems.  This is likely a moot issue once we can finally get centos8 out the door.  The locking prevents the actual refetching of the layers because we check if the layer already exists on the disk. While we end up "reprocessing" the layers over and over (thanks containers), we don't actually go to the source to refetch it once I added locking.  Previously we were actually concurrently fetching the same layers. We reduced this impact by 1) shuffling the containers so that we don't concurrently process the same service containers (e.g. cinder-api, cinder-volume, cinder-backup, etc) and 2) adding locking to prevent the same layer from being worked on if it's already in the process of being fetched.  Once the layer is on disk and been pushed to the registry, we unlock it which allows the locked containers to start the processing. One of the actions is to check if the layer is already available and if so then do the filesystem hard link. Thats why we end up with log messages indicating that the layers are being locked/unlocked.

So there's a race condition somewhere, likely because these layers are small layers. We aren't duplicating the fetch for all of them. For example in my log, I had the following for a bunch of containers:

neutron_fwaas/services/firewall/fwaas_pl.message:
Let us modify this function as shown below.
def _get_hosts_to_notify(self, context, router_ids):
        """Returns all hosts to send notification about firewall update"""
        l3_plugin = directory.get_plugin(plugin_constants.L3)
        no_broadcast = (
            extensions.is_extension_supported(
                l3_plugin, nl_constants.L3_AGENT_SCHEDULER_EXT_ALIAS) and
            getattr(l3_plugin, 'get_l3_agents_hosting_routers', False))
        scheduled_rtr_hosts = set()
        if no_broadcast:
            # This call checks for all scheduled routers to the network node
            agents = l3_plugin.get_l3_agents_hosting_routers(
                context, router_ids, admin_state_up=True, active=True)
            scheduled_rtr_hosts = set([a.host for a in agents])
        dvr_broadcast = (
                extensions.is_extension_supported(
                    l3_plugin, nl_constants.L3_AGENT_SCHEDULER_EXT_ALIAS) and
                getattr(l3_plugin, '_get_dvr_hosts_for_router', False))
        unscheduled_dvr_hosts = set()
        if dvr_broadcast:
            # Now check for unscheduled DVR router on distributed compute hosts
            for router_id in router_ids:
                hosts = set(l3_plugin._get_dvr_hosts_for_router(
                    context, router_id))
                unscheduled_dvr_hosts |= hosts
        if no_broadcast or dvr_broadcast:
            total_hosts = scheduled_rtr_hosts.union(unscheduled_dvr_hosts)
            return total_hosts

        # NOTE(blallau): default: FirewallAgentAPI performs RPC broadcast
        return [None]

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This is not the only, and, in fact, the least harmful deviation from the standard.

Way more painful problem is the necessity to reboot the system upon changing boot device. This requirement gets even more nastier when combined with the need to change boot mode - both operations require node reboot *and* these two reboots can't be queued one by the other. Instead, the client needs to wait for the first reboot to complete, and only then the second reboot request would be accepted by iDRAD.

These hassles are being taken care of (partially) by the sushy-oem-dellemc extension.

driver-requirements.txt.message:
should this be ">" not "<"?
I think it will work with 0.1.0 exactly. Not sure about 0.0.x ones?

This states ironic's dependency on the sushy-oem-idrac Python package can be satisfied by versions less than or equal to 0.1.0. The only existing release is 0.0.2, and it satisfies the dependency.

sushy-oem-idrac uses Semantic Versioning [1].

[1] https://semver.org/
Why would this be limited to less than 0.1.0?  What happens in the future if there a later version?  Is this a typo or intentional?
I'm good.  Just wanted to ensure it was intentionally submitted and not a typo.

Well, this package is very new and might evolve. So I thought to pin ironic to reasonably current version for now. Before the next ironic release we might unpin it.

Do you think I am being too cautious?
For versions in 0.x range, every minor version is considered breaking, so this is fine. We should aim to reach 1.0.0 asap, of course.

ironic/drivers/drac.py.message: Is that applicable for UEFI and legacy modes?
Yes, all three (3) of those boot interfaces are supported for both the UEFI and legacy BIOS boot modes.
Any reason not to make it go first? I would expect it to be the preferred option, if enabled

It is consistent with the management and boot Redfish interfaces for which support was recently added. They are last and have the lowest priority. Please see below. That was described by the specification -- https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/blame/commit/30d869182d259a3f2dbb01f5673ee78242b26007/specs/approved/idrac-support-of-redfish-interfaces.rst#L196-L209

Also, couldn't making it go first be a breaking change which should be deprecated? If not breaking, it feels like it would make it more confusing for operators who wish to create some, but not all, new nodes with the new interface? That is the rationale behind what is described by the specification.

And it makes me wonder. What would Pixie Boots do?

author.name: Julia Kreger

>>> print('that\'s required for this node to boot from virtual ')
that's required for this node to boot from virtual 
>>> print('that's required for this node to boot from virtual ')
  File "<input>", line 1
    print('that's required for this node to boot from virtual ')
                ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
>>>

I have replaced the single quotes with double quotes to eliminate the need for the escape character.

ironic/tests/unit/drivers/test_drac.py.message: I don't quite understand why this change is needed.  Doesn't this imply that the default boot interface has changed from pxe.PXEBoot to ipxe.iPXEBoot?  I don't think we would want the default boot interface to change as a result of this patch.

All of that makes sense, but in that case, the original code would be using ipxe.iPXEBoot as the default boot interface, and the original assert as written on the left would have failed.  In order for the original assert to work, the default boot interface must have been pxe.PXEBoot.  That's the discrepancy that I don't understand...

This class formerly relied on the configuration of ‘enabled_boot_interfaces’ performed by its base classes. Please see https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/ac55c642e492a54e41c095df00db25cc29719110/ironic/tests/base.py#L144-L145

It now does that itself above.

Ah, I understand now.  Thanks for the explanation.  For posterity: When enabled_boot_interfaces was not specified, the base class enabled only pxe.  That's what made the code on the left work.  The default was and is ipxe, but because ipxe wasn't enabled, pxe was what was actually used.  This change enables pxe, ipxe, and redfish virtual media, so because the default of ipxe is enabled, that is what is now used.  This test case could have not enabled ipxe, in which case, the change to the line above would not have been necessary.  Enabling all 3 is probably a better way to test it though.

This change does not change the default boot interface. Rather, it appends the new drac.boot.DracRedfishVirtualMediaBoot interface to the list of boot interfaces that have been supported, making it the lowest priority among the supported interfaces.

Prior to this, that list was defined by the base class of the idrac hardware type, ironic.drivers.generic.GenericHardware, as follows:

    @property
    def supported_boot_interfaces(self):
        """List of supported boot interfaces."""
        return [ipxe.iPXEBoot, pxe.PXEBoot]

Please see https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/8912c061c63e2c56a56cd952ba0431631dfece98/ironic/drivers/generic.py#L44-L46

This validates that when the highest priority supported boot interface is enabled and a node does not have its boot_interface field set, that highest priority supported interface is used. ipxe.iPXEBoot is the highest priority supported interface.

I believe you get the gist of it. However, be careful with terminology! :)

The concept of default interface is different from the priority ordered list of supported interfaces. Please see the description in the "Driver composition reform" specification which introduced the hardware type concept -- https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/blame/commit/733990b24583b31624aa3c9ab83cc3fecb6c6c60/specs/approved/driver-composition-reform.rst#L146-L159

It turns out the 'default_boot_interface' is set to None by the base class. And because it is not set, it is not used.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Would you describe the details? If it's a bug, I wish you report it on https://bugs.launchpad.net/watcher.

Hi licanwei,

Thank you for reviewing this patch. Me and my team are working on an OpenStack Rocky deployment and we would love to utilize watcher. During our tests we faced the following issues:

1) VM Consolidation Strategy expects configuration option datasource and this is fine. At the same time, the DataSourceManager class expects to find datasources. This is a bug which is not present to later stable branches due to a big refactor which is not backported to stable/rocky.
2) Gnocchi's statistic_aggregation method had default aggregation kwarg set to 'avg'. This is a bug because there is no such aggregation to gnocchi, only 'mean'. This is not present to later stable branches due to another big refactor
3) We found out that if for some reason ceilometer could not get some metrics for an instance, then the watcher fails because gnocchi does not contain any data. This is why we added the filter 'ACTIVE' because our stopped or failed instances does not have their metrics collected. We would expect watcher to work with the active instances rather than failing miserably. I do not know if this is the intention or a bug.
about 3), I think it's a bug, you can report a bug and paste the error message. Maybe it's better to check the instance status before getting metrics.

cinder/api/views/backups.py.message: This looks like it risks overloading some assumptions further down the stack, because "backups/detail" is probably not actually a "collection name"?

The REST api for backups is /v3/{project_id}/backups/detail[0] or /v2/{project_id}/backups/detail[1]. So not only for v3 but also for v2 is backups/detail.

We will generate the next link here[2]. And If we do not set '/detail' in collection_name, when we try to get backups by this link(eg: default value of osapi_max_limit is 1000, and we have 1001 backups), we will only get summary info of backups.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#list-backups-with-detail
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v2/index.html#backups-backups
BTW, if we do not use '/detail' here, the new unit test will be failure.

OK so the issue is we can't update the dest host attachment while the source host attachment is still on the volume. Normal resize will create the empty dest host attachment and delete the source host attachment during resize_instance, we're not doing that same kind of thing. Details after discussing this with Sean McGinnis:

(11:08:18 AM) mriedem: so i thought i knew how this worked in cinder but i might have forgotten. if i boot from volume i've got an in-use volume. then if i'm going to migrate the server, nova will create an "empty" volume attachment for the dest host - this is a volume attachment without a connector, and the volume status changes to "attaching",
(11:09:11 AM) mriedem: now when nova updates the dest host attachment with the connector, it should make the volume as in-use again right? i'm seeing a failure like this instead: "Invalid input received: Invalid volume: Volume  b2aba195-6570-40c4-82bb-46d3557fceeb status must be available or  downloading to reserve, but the current status is attaching."
(11:09:39 AM) mriedem: maybe the issue is i haven't deleted the source host attachment yet?
(11:12:58 AM) smcginnis: mriedem: Looking at blame in the code, doesn't appear we've ever allowed that with the new attach APIs.
(11:12:59 AM) mriedem: ah yeah i think that's the problem. looking at how nova does a migration, we create the empty dest host attachment first which reserves the volume, then we delete the source host attachment, and once we migrate to the dest host, we update the dest host attachment with the connector and finally complete it to mark the volume as in-use
(11:13:17 AM) smcginnis: We sepcifically only check for available or downloading and also allow in-use only if multiattach is set.
(11:13:46 AM) mriedem: yeah...shazbot, my cross-cell stuff has hit a snag for volume-backed servers then...
(11:14:34 AM) mriedem: i'm trying to sniff out if a dest host is going to work in another cell by creating an export there first (updating the attachment using the dest host connector), but i haven't deleted the existing source host attachment for the volume, which is different from how normal resize works
(11:15:00 AM) smcginnis: Yeah, that could be tricky.
(11:15:36 AM) smcginnis: We could add "attaching", but I think we would need to enforce that the update is for the same host that started the attachment or something to prevent a race of someone else coming in and attaching it.
(11:15:37 AM) mriedem: i'd have to (1) create the dest host empty attachment, (2) delete the source host attachment, (3) update the dest host attachment with the dest host connector, and failing that, re-connect the source host attachment
(11:15:47 AM) smcginnis: Which I think defeats the purpose of having that "reserved" state.
(11:16:04 AM) smcginnis: mriedem: That sounds reasonable.
(11:16:18 AM) mriedem: reasonable, but pretty sucky
(11:16:24 AM) mriedem: i.e. lots of things to go wrong there
(11:17:46 AM) mriedem: but without creating the export on the dest host we don't really have a good pre-check that that host will work
(11:17:47 AM) mriedem: right?
(11:18:38 AM) smcginnis: I think you are right.
(11:18:59 AM) smcginnis: We would have to add a new API call to validate that beforehand.

This makes it sound to me like it does some specific cross-cell resize sanity checks, but AFAICT, it does not. All this is doing is claiming (and the associated notifications) right?

Oh and this also used to update volume attachments to get a new connection_info for this host and make a connection to the volume on the host but I had to remove that for complicated reasons (the attachment counting and tracking gets messed up). So anyway, point is this used to do more than the claim.

Yeah, this docstring is likely an artifact of when this method had cross_cell in the name. Can re-word this in a follow up, but also didn't really want this being confused with prep_resize for same-cell resize. Trying to tip-toe around these new methods as only being used for cross-cell resize/migrate but calling them snapshot-based is kind of difficult, since there are some assumptions built into these methods about how they are being used during a cross-cell resize flow.
Done

This seems like an odd thing to return, as it's nearly an internal piece of the instance. I guess I need to go see what you do with this when you actually call this later in the series, but I would expect an instance.refresh() at the caller might be better.

I'll check your comments on the task code that uses this. In my mind the caller needs to know about the migration_context either way, so if the caller gets the value back directly or refreshes to get it, we're tightly coupled to behavior in this method, e.g. refreshing in conductor means we have a contract on this method storing the instance.migration_context anyway. I feel like the explicit return is more straight-forward - and faster than a fresh pull from the DB with all the already-joined fields.

This seems a little dangerous. get_allocs_for_consumer() returns the raw response from placement if things seemed to succeed. Ideally that will always be stable (or we get an exception) but if we were to change that format and iterate the global placement microversion we use, we could forget to change this and crash here.

Also note that this could raise ConsumerAllocationRetrievalFailed, which your docstring doesn't say is expected (nor probably should it). Maybe this should go one line down so we raise MigrationPreCheckError in case that happens?

I was just following what _prep_resize does but I guess that uses get_allocations_for_consumer and I used get_allocs_for_consumer since there is a todo on get_allocations_for_consumer not to use it. But get_allocations_for_consumer calls get_allocs_for_consumer and just returns the ['allocations'] entry. But I can move this within the try/except to make it result in a migration error if it blows up.
Done and added a test to make sure we get the allocations within the try/except block.

Looked it a bit deeper into what would it take to support qos port during cross cell resize.

* Populating of the request_spec.requested_resource is done before the MigrationTask is forking out to the CrossCellMigrationTask [2]. Nothing to do there.

* Calculating the request group rp mapping is done also in the MigrationTask._schedule() call before forking out to the CrossCellMigrationTask. Nothing to do there.

* At finish resize we need to update the neutron port binding with the allocation key based on the mapping. You have a TODO in [3]. But I added some comments there as you need to extend the RPC call with the RequestSpec to be able to implement the TODO.

* InstancePciRequests needs to be updated here, before the resize_claim() call, to driver the pci_claim during resize_claim to allocate VFs from the same PF as the bandwidth was allocated from. Same as what we do in prep_resize [1]. To do that you need to have access to the RequestSpec so prep_snapshot_based_resize_at_dest needs to be extended.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/7058fac53b8e6f5ca31baa4afa1b8994a487914c/nova/compute/manager.py#L4618
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635668/45/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py@341
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635080/43/nova/compute/manager.py@5375
Done - added the request_spec parameter and a TODO.

Why are we making this a long-call? Because we could take a while to call placement for the allocs? I mean, we could make all our calls long-calls I think, I'm just curious what you're specifically worried about here.

Oh I guess you're not asking why this is a call, just why is it a long call? It doesn't really have to be I guess, I wouldn't expect getting allocations or the resize claim to take longer than 60 seconds, so IDK, I guess it's just the pattern I set into with this series.

Per the spec, everything is a blocking call in the cross-cell resize flow once we get to the new task(s) in conductor that drive the operation. The computes aren't casting back and forth like same-cell resize and the computes aren't casting back to the superconductor when they are done.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: This is the "root" of the problem, right? Could we not do the brackets thing here to limit the blast radius?
I had considered adding the brackets back in the inject_method called here, but it seemed cleaner to not remove them in the first place than to remove them and then put them back

Adding them back here would entail assuming that a) the last colon delineates the port, and b) any other colons imply IPv6. These things should be true, but that logic is better off living in one place.

It's mainly because it clearly makes no sense for the `host` part of a `host:port` string to have colons in it and not be bracketed; and so I want the code that makes sure this doesn't happen to be very close to the code that assembles the host and port into a single colon-separated string. Here is not that.

I agree it'd be ugly to re-add them here. I guess it comes down to what's less ugly: re-add them here, or do it at the source with the caveat that there's no obviously visible link between the code here that needs brackets and the code that actually adds them. Looks like folks are favouring the latter, and I'm fine with that. Since get_model apparently isn't used by anything else, it should be safe.

manila/api/v2/share_networks.py.message:
rephrase this slightly so we can convey more info:

 The share network %(id)s does not have a 'default' subnet 
 that serves all availability zones, so subnet
 details ('neutron_net_id', 'neutron_subnet_id') cannot
 be updated.
Great. Really looks better in the way you suggested. Thanks

BadRequest

 

The entity that wasn't found is not part of the URI - so this can't be HTTP404,

 

HTTP404 is cacheable by clients - if, they went ahead and created a subnet and then decided to update the network, the client could stop the request by replaying its cache.

Should be:

 update_values.get('neutron_net_id') is None or 
  update_values.get('neutron_subnet_id') is None

So that you can also prevent updates where either value is null..

web/src/actions/build.js.message: The removal of this line is showing a problem with the failure detection (see next comment).

The removal of stats.failures is showing a problem with checking the return code here.  Previously, we would only look for tasks with non-zero return codes if there was a failure.  Now we always do.  But sometimes there are legitimate non-zero return codes which aren't failures.  For example:

http://logs.openstack.org/97/633697/3/check/zuul-build-dashboard/4460c4a/npm/html/build/ce79c722944448be9ddd739b84af494d

This makes the play summary very confusing, as it looks like it just pulled out two tasks at random.  Should we just not check the return code, and only test for .failed?
There are indeed false positive now. Checking for .failed only should be better, good catch thanks.
